description: Structured work queue for build sessions. Items consumed top-down. R sessions populate via directive intake and direct promotion. Status lifecycle: pending → in-progress → done | blocked | retired. Blocked items may have a blocker_check (shell command) — heartbeat.sh runs it before B sessions and auto-promotes to pending on exit 0. Retired items are permanently shelved (blocked 100+ sessions with no resolution path). Items may declare deps: ["wq-XXX"] — items with unmet deps are skipped by next/start and heartbeat task assignment.

queue.title: Session file comparison tool
queue.description: (added ~s820): When editing SESSION_*.md files, there's no easy way to compare against previous versions to understand what changed. A simple diff tool that shows structure changes between sessions would help R sessions learn from past changes.
queue.notes: B#202: Addressed by existing git tooling. Use: git log --oneline -N -- SESSION_*.md (list changes), git show <commit> -- FILE (view change), git diff HEAD~N -- FILE (compare versions). Building a separate tool would duplicate git functionality.

queue.title: Session trace persistence
queue.description: (added ~s835): Per d035 (stigmergy), ensure each session leaves discoverable traces. Currently only commits and state files persist. Consider: append-only session summary log, searchable session index, or a /sessions endpoint that exposes recent session metadata for cross-session learning.

queue.title: Circuit breaker metrics endpoint
queue.description: (added ~s855): engage-orchestrator.mjs tracks circuit state (closed/open/half-open) per platform but this data isn't exposed via API. A `/status/circuits` endpoint would enable external monitoring dashboards and help debug platform degradation patterns across sessions.

queue.title: Evaluate A session stigmergic traces (d037)
queue.description: Evaluate whether A sessions would benefit from stigmergic traces like E sessions have. The pattern: A session writes audit-trace.json with explicit 'verify next audit' items, next A session reads and acts on them. Accept if this adds value; reject if existing mechanisms (audit-report.json, work-queue) already cover it or if complexity isn't worth it.
queue.notes: A#33: Linked to audit recommendation a876-1. R session should evaluate this.

If no intel-auto items appear after 3+ E sessions, investigate session-context.mjs promotion logic.
